item.title: "In a desperate answer to a dire problem, San Francisco is...
item.content:encoded:
Denver Homeless Out Loud

"In a desperate answer to a dire problem, San Francisco is setting up sanctioned homeless encampments throughout the city — becoming the first in the region to embrace a dramatic policy shift that would have seemed far-fetched just a few months ago.

After watching the number of tents within its borders increase by 71% during the coronavirus pandemic, San Francisco opened its first temporary, city-organized encampment this month — a fenced-off piece of asphalt with dozens of t...ents right outside City Hall. Two others are set to open within days, with more likely to come.

It’s a controversial strategy that’s sparked pushback from neighbors worried about safety, and from activists who argue the camps are neither humane nor sufficient for the scope of the problem. But proponents, including Mayor London Breed, say they’re the best option available. And while other major Bay Area cities mostly have avoided adopting city-organized encampments for years — despite their expanding homeless populations — some outreach workers say it’s time to embrace the inevitable."

item.title: "The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention recommends...
item.content:encoded:
Denver Homeless Out Loud

"The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention recommends that officials not disturb tent encampments during the coronavirus pandemic unless people are given individual hotel rooms, as homeless advocates want to see. Those advocates say providing a safe space where people can get meals, use a toilet and avoid harassing passers-by is a reasonable option given the times.

“The best, best option would be housing. The second-best option would be hotel rooms, but if you can’t do that and we’re going to have so many people outside then I think it makes sense ... to make those outside as safe as can be,” said Dr. Margot Kushel, director of the Center for Vulnerable Populations at the University of California, San Francisco."

item.title: DHOL received multiple calls and a message from Wedlocks Bridal...
item.content:encoded:
Denver Homeless Out Loud

DHOL received multiple calls and a message from Wedlocks Bridal Hair and Makeup on 21st st. There is a small camp outside of their office and wanted some assistance with some issues they were having. I went to the camp. I know the residents there well. Very well. I spoke with them, then went into Wedlocks to speak to the owner. Michelle who goes by "Nine" was relieved to see me after reaching out for help. We talked a bit. She was told by DPD not to engage with the camp resid...ents, advice she followed which she now regrets. She felt like things had gotten out of hand and she didn't know how to real it back in. I asked her how I could help. She wanted to find common ground and have some agreements around coexisting. I offered to facilitate a conversation with her and the camp residents. We went outside and had a chat. They got to know a little bit about one another and then hashed out some agreements. They agreed to work together for their mutual survival (residents and business together). When I left they were all sitting on the sidewalk in a circle talking and laughing. Another way is possible and we can all be part of the solution. Choice is yours.

item.title: Credit:John Staughton (Volunteer extraordinaire and...
item.content:encoded:
Denver Homeless Out Loud

Credit:John Staughton (Volunteer extraordinaire and Abolitionist)

+6John Staughton is in Denver, Colorado. · Instagram

Over the past 3 days, Denver violently evicted 100+ unhoused humans before a record-breaking snowfall arriving tonight.

There have already been 15 sweeps in 20...21, and while every displacement is inhumane, this week’s criminal cruelty will be hard to forget.

On Tuesday, a camp of ~20 people at Lafayette and Park was destroyed. The last two residents who remained by 9am—independent women of color well-known in the community—have been swept 5+ times in the past 6 months. City workers were rushing, or just didn’t care, because as Didi wheeled one of her carts outside the fenced-in area, EHS and their bobcat scooped up her cooler and other storage bins, crushing them in the 2 minutes it took her to return.

On Wednesday, the city demolished 5 small, well-maintained camps (50+ people) in the Baker neighborhood. This sprawling operation brought out 19 police officers, but only 4 mental health workers. The worst moments? A city employee (EHS) mocking a resident during a mental health episode, an EHS supervisor threatening to “beat your ass” to a resident who wasn’t packing up fast enough. That SAME supervisor later stole an axe from a resident, and was recorded putting it in his truck. There was an attempted illegal sweep of 3 indigenous folx outside the posted eviction area. All this heinous shit was caught on camera.

On Thursday, the curbside camp of ~25 people at Colfax and Washington was obliterated. Nearby business owners - Argonaut Wine & Liquor and Cheba Hut "Toasted" Subs - called the cops on mutual aid workers, advocates, and members of the press for “trespassing” in the empty lots outside the fences. We were physically threatened by testosterone-drunk security guards working for a private firm called Ronin Asset Protection. Before the sweep was even over, employees from Argonaut Liquors installed anti-homeless fencing on the whole block.

Two weeks ago, at least 5 people froze to death, another 30 landed in burn wards, many losing fingers and toes. DestabilizIng 100+ people before an even bigger storm is appalling, but Mayor Hancock and his gang of cops & contractors clearly care more about corporate interests and property than human lives.

Fuck all of this.
STOP THE SWEEPS

item.title: This is code. What is the city really up to? Let us help you....
item.content:encoded:
Denver Homeless Out Loud

This is code. What is the city really up to? Let us help you. This is all about optics. The city is determined to spend the money on anything but meeting real needs of folks in encampments let us explain.

“new partnership between 311 and the Early Intervention Team”

This is code for let us send in someone who answers to a direct appointee of the Mayor, that way the real-estate lobby will be calling the shots. There is outcry in the STAR program pilot, for community oversi...ght and the city is trying to say “let us handle it internally” where have we heard that before? The EIT team is an attempt to get around the potential of community oversight of the STAR program leaving the real-estate lobby our Mayor serves in control of the alternative EIT.

“ more stable options than living on the streets,”
Notice the absence of the word housing, That is on purpose. The city does not want to invest in housing, certainly not at the scale of the need. They reserve land development opportunities for the real-estate lobby (who only want to make luxury scale units which they advertise this as “market rate”. So instead of the city building housing outside of the monopolized private market, at the city's response is to instead try and “fix” the poor so the poor can someday afford what the real-esate lobby expects everyone else to pay for housing. You will NOT find budget housing development projects. The real-estate lobby refuses to build a budget housing projects. This is a city where 87% of the renters make less than 35K per year.
What a market for budget apartments! What an opportunity for the city to push the real-estate lobby to build what we need instead of forcing 87% of renters in the city to pay what real-estate developers want. It does not work that way does it? The Real-estate lobby has bought the Mayor to make sure that the city works to meet developers needs instead of the other way around.
You will not find in this anything that meets the direct needs of encampments. Things like trash removal service and access to bathrooms. It is designed to relocate people one way or another either to a warehouse situation or just “away” without building the needed units of housing.

item.title: Yesterday morning, DPD, DOTI, DDPHE, The Mayor's office,...
item.content:encoded:
Denver Homeless Out Loud

Yesterday morning, DPD, DOTI, DDPHE, The Mayor's office, and EHS were at 10th and Bannock traumatically displacing residents during a SWEEP. Approximately 40 people were forced to leave. It was bitterly cold (12 degrees) with nearly a foot of snow and ice. Most residents of this camp moved only a block or two. While volunteers were helping residents pack and move, housed neighbors preemptively put up fencing to prohibit human survival.
STOP THE INSANITY! The commodification ...of humans for profit must cease! We need to stop turning against one another and understand that THIS issue is central to all issues: The right to exist on this planet. One thing we (the fence erectors and DHOL) could agree on is that no one should have to live in a tent. We need to unite and demand HOUSING FOR ALL from our government. The US Declaration of Independence is clear that when : " a long train of abuses and usurpations, pursuing invariably the same Object evinces a design to reduce them under absolute Despotism, it is their right, it is their DUTY to throw off such Government, and to provide new Guards for their future security." Regarding oppressive policies and procedures the Declaration of Independence states: "We have Petitioned for Redress in the most humble terms: Our repeated Petitions have been answered only by repeated injury. A Prince whose character is thus marked by every act which may define a Tyrant (Mayor Hancock), is unfit to be the ruler of a free people."
We march onward towards Rights, Dignity, Housing....
